issues.description: The problem statement's UML declares a Pneumatic interface with methods raisePressure(int) and openValve(), but the solution repository's Pneumatic interface declares raisePressure(int) and releasePressure() (no openValve). Meanwhile the solution's LaunchedDropdownTower and LaunchedRollerCoaster classes implement Pneumatic but provide openValve() (not releasePressure). This creates a structural mismatch across artifacts: the UML (and intended exercise) expects openValve(), the solution's interface uses releasePressure(), and the solution classes use openValve(), which makes the solution internally inconsistent and would not compile. Students following the UML will declare openValve(), which will not match the solution's Pneumatic; conversely, using the solution interface as given will not match the Launched* classes.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the Pneumatic interface consistent with the UML and with the Launched* classes. Either: (A) Change the solution repository's Pneumatic interface to declare openValve() (and remove releasePressure()), so it matches the UML and the Launched* classes (they already implement openValve()); or (B) Update the problem statement/UML and the Launched* classes to use releasePressure() instead of openValve(), ensuring all three artifacts use the same method name and signatures. Option A is simplest here because the UML explicitly specifies openValve().

issues.description: The UML/problem statement defines the Pneumatic interface with methods raisePressure(int) and openValve(). In the solution repository the Pneumatic interface declares raisePressure(int) and releasePressure(), while the concrete classes (LaunchedRollerCoaster and LaunchedDropdownTower) override openValve(). This creates a naming mismatch: the problem expects an openValve() method but the solution interface uses releasePressure(). The inconsistency will confuse students mapping the UML to the code and also leads to an internal mismatch in the solution (implementing classes use openValve but the interface declares releasePressure), which can cause compilation errors or uncertainty about the correct method name to implement.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the method name across artifacts. Recommended: rename the solution interface method releasePressure() to openValve() (i.e., in solution_repository/src/de/tum/in/ase/Pneumatic.java change releasePressure() to openValve()), and ensure all implementing classes (LaunchedRollerCoaster, LaunchedDropdownTower) match that name. Alternatively, if releasePressure() is preferred, update the UML/problem statement to use releasePressure() and update the implementing classes accordingly. Prefer making the solution match the problem/UML to avoid student confusion.
